Award.AwardTitle: Linking Spatial and Spectral Transport in Two-Dimensional Fluid Flow
Award.AbstractNarration:
****Technical Abstract****

Predicting the behavior of nonlinear, nonequilibrium systems remains a tremendous challenge for condensed matter physics. Since they are out of equilibrium, they tend to move, leading to a flow of energy and momentum throughout the system. But since they are nonlinear, energy and momentum may also be redistributed among the various degrees of freedom in the system. This project seeks to understand the relationship between these two kinds of transport in a turbulent quasi-two-dimensional laboratory fluid flow, a model system with a very large number of strongly coupled degrees of freedom. Using powerful tools known as filter-space techniques, measurements of the spatially resolved spectral energy fluxes will be made, and will subsequently be correlated with the spatial transport of energy in the flow. These two kinds of transport will also be linked to the self-organized coherent structures in the flow field. The project will support the training of a Ph.D. student in both the experiments and the novel computational analysis tools that will be developed.

***Non-Technical Abstract****

Physical systems that are far from equilibrium and that are governed by nonlinear equations of motion, such as fluid flows or many biological systems, are extremely common in nature. Characterizing and predicting their behavior, however, remains a significant challenge, both because they tend to move in complicated ways and because perturbations tend to excite responses on many different length and time scales. By using high precision laboratory experiments and novel analysis tools, this project seeks to understand how the flow of energy in space is related to the flow of energy between motions of different scales. Experiments will be conducted in a nearly two-dimensional turbulent fluid flow, and computational analysis will be used to measure the flow of energy both in space and between length scales. These measurements will lead to a better understanding of the flow dynamics, with consequences for models of geophysical flows in the atmosphere and oceans, and will reveal the mechanisms by which the flow self-organizes into coherent structures. A Ph.D. student will be trained in both nonlinear physics and fluid dynamics, gaining valuable skills that are transferable to many other disciplines. The results of this research will lead to a deeper understanding of turbulent fluid flows and to nonlinear systems more broadly, and may lead to new ways of characterize strongly coupled condensed matter systems.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Turbulent flows are tremendously complex, and modeling their behavior remains a significant challenge. Their violent and seemingly erratic fluctuations lead to the transport of material, energy, and momentum both from place to place in space but also between a vast range of different length and time scales. Part of this transport can be well modeled as random, but a surprising amount is ordered and directed. The goal of this project was to clarify the ways in which the movement of energy in space and its transfer between different scales of motion are linked, in order to enable new kinds of models of turbulence (and other nonlinear systems) in the future. 

To achieve this goal, we developed a set of analysis tools that allowed us to localize and visualize the flow of energy in space in between scales in experimental data. Although the basic methods of these tools had been previously developed, we extended them in several ways with support from this grant. In particular, we were able to identify the particular kinds of interactions that tend to be responsible for driving energy to smaller or larger length scales, respectively, and which tend to keep energy at a single length scale but to create spatial patterns. Using these ideas, we were then able to reduce the question of why some quantities preferentially flow to larger or smaller length scales to a geometry problem: what matters is the relative alignment of various quantities in space. This notion of alignment and geometry led us to discover a surprising transition to spatial order buried within the turbulent dynamics, and to branch out to unraveling some longstanding puzzles related to the alignment of vorticity (that is, the tendency of a flow to spin) and strain (that is, the tendency of the flow to stretch) in turbulence. These findings may lead to new ways to model the dynamics of turbulence that are more tractable than current approaches. 

In a related line of research, we explored how the energy transfer between scales is related to coherent structures in the flow (that is, regions of the flow field that can be distinguished from the rest and that keep their identities for long periods of time). We showed that the flux of energy between scales is tightly connected to the motion of the fluid, and in particular that regions with different properties are bounded by objects known as Lagrangian Coherent Structures, relatively recently discovered features that reveal the underlying mixing skeleton of the flow. But we also found that we could correlate the ways in which the energy fluxes change in time with simpler, more well known coherent structures that are easily measurable, and made suggestions for how this observation may enable some new kinds of forecasting.

This project also had several broader impacts. Several junior researchers were trained in research, and have successfully gone on to further research positions. A simple experimental apparatus related to the research done in the project was developed that was used for undergraduate education, and additionally for outreach in local K-12 schools. And finally, several of the software tools developed during this project, including the particle-tracking software that was used to run the experiments, were made publicly available to other researchers and educators.
